awd_titl_txt: Type I: Rutgers University I-Corps Site for Entrepreneurship Acceleration
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from Rutgers University, creates an NSF I-Corps Site at this institution.

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

Rutgers University has funded research of over $600M per year. This research generates over 150 patents each year and more than $15M in licensing income annually. A challenge is to transition research outcomes to the commercialization stage. The Rutgers University I-Corps Site cultivates this pool of early stage ideas and assists with bringing viable concepts through the commercialization pathway to the marketplace. Through the I-Corps Site, with targeted training and mentoring, I-Corps teams are sourced from the Rutgers Site partners. These include the Office of Research Commercialization, educational activities ranging from the Collaboration for Technology Entrepreneurship and Commercialization (CTEC) and Professional Science Master's (PSM) programs, senior-year "capstone" engineering design and Honors College programs, and many other feeder programs. Mentors are matched to these teams. Inventors benefit from the larger innovation ecosystem in the New Jersey/New York region, as the Site partners with the NYCRIN I-Corps Node. 

The Rutgers I-Corps Site provides training, mentoring, and access to a large network of business, technical and financial resources. The signature activity of this program is that each year, 30 teams participate and test the commercial potential of their products with a broad base of consumers. This program promotes the value of commercialization to both faculty and students, and reinforces the concept that ideas generated by the academic research process can have societal and commercial value.

The Rutgers I-Corps bridges the gap between the lab and the marketplace, enhancing the University's commitment to fostering economic development across New Jersey and beyond. As the number of spin-outs from the university increases, jobs are created and companies hire students as interns and graduates as full-time employees. The program's impact goes beyond the University by tapping into local business leaders and entrepreneurs for team mentorship as well as expanding programs to support the communities around Rutgers campuses and to particularly assist underrepresented inventors and business-owners. A key area of focus is to increase I-Corps participation from women in STEM and ultimately to increase the number of women-owned businesses in the region/state.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our I-Corps@Rutgers Site nurtured the pool of early-stage innovators at Rutgers and facilitated better understanding of the innovator?s technologies? commercialization potential. We helped teams develop strategies to find ?product-market fit? and reach out to potential customers helping them fine-tune their specific value propositions.  We educated teams on resources that can help further their innovations, with a focus on sources of future funding, to help them bridge the ?Valley of Death?.

Through our I-Corps@Rutgers Site, we created a bigger and better innovation ecosystem at Rutgers and extending it out to the region and have provided significant support to teams to help move their innovations closer to commercialization. Rutgers technology transfer office recognizes the value in teams that have completed the I-Corps program.  Their Innovation Ventures team created a ?Road to Commercialization? Symposium Series as a requirement for researchers applying to their two signature funding programs TechAdvance and HealthAdvance.   I-Corps is a featured program in the series which is offered quarterly.

One unique highlight was the creation of an I-Corps Diversity Fellowship Program. The new Diversity Fellowship Program was aimed at underrepresented students from Rutgers and nearby Minority Serving Institutions. Our goal was to find diverse students with an interest in innovation & entrepreneurship and help them learn about Lean Launchpad Startup, the Business Model Canvas, and Customer Discovery ? all cornerstones of the I-Corps National curriculum. I-Corps Fellows meaningfully contributed to existing regional I-Corps Team by supporting the entrepreneurial lead as a co-Entrepreneurial Lead or as a Cohort Fellow supporting the Teaching Team.  This pioneering program is now being adopted by the NSF I-Corps Hub in the Northeast.

The Fellows who participated gave presentations about their I-Corps Journey at the end of their Fellowship.  We learned that the Fellowship experience provided an opportunity to foster their interest in innovation and in a number of cases, changed the students? career trajectories.  The majority of Fellows commented that they gained confidence by participating in the program and it made them want to try other new and different opportunities.

The Fellowship Program was presented at the VentureWell Open 2021 virtual conference.  The poster:  Breaking Down Barriers with I-Crops Fellowships was presented during the afternoon Poster Session.  We learned that this is the only program of its kind in the National Innovation Network.

 


Last Modified: 05/20/2023
Modified by: Dunbar P Birnie

    Mark DeGuzman

    Breakout with Faculty Technical Leads
  • Key leaders of the I-Corps@Rutgers Site presented the Diversity Fellowship Program at VentureWell 2021. This program, a supplement to the original Rutgers I-Corps Site award, enabled significant broadening of participation in innovation activities and is being continued in the Northeast I-Corps Hub.
    Lori Dars and Mark DeGuzman
    Creative Commons
    Dunbar P Birnie
    I-Corps Diversity Fellowship Program Advantages
